    "slug": "connections-breaking-barriers-shattering-ceilings",
    "url": "/events/connections-breaking-barriers-shattering-ceilings",
    "img": "//web.archive.org/web/20230925131719/https://images.ctfassets.net/22n7d68fswlw/5v5OIsz5wp60GPhp2OQ5FA/97e3bebdec76ba4aa48df0ae4fff3f31/connections.jpg",
    "posterUrl": "//web.archive.org/web/20230925131719/https://images.ctfassets.net/22n7d68fswlw/5v5OIsz5wp60GPhp2OQ5FA/97e3bebdec76ba4aa48df0ae4fff3f31/connections.jpg",
    "description": "<p>Representation matters is a common refrain when speaking about inclusion in the industry. Yet, when it comes to representation both onscreen and behind the scenes, people with disabilities continue to be woefully underrepresented, if not outright ignored, facing a range of accessibility barriers to meaningful participation and inclusion. Join us to learn about how organizations and industry professionals are fighting for greater representation and accessibility, through the creation of the Disability Screen Office and the development of vital programming, how to identify and overcome critical barriers, and how to engage in the urgent work that lies ahead to ensure that our industry reflects and serves people with disabilities.</p>\r\n\r\n<p>This session will be hosted in an accessible venue space with ASL and captioning provided.</p>",

The Disability Screen Office is a national, disability-led, not-for-profit organization that works with the Canadian screen industry to eliminate accessibility barriers and foster authentic and meaningful disability representation throughout the sector.\nWinnie is a disability advocate, 2SLGBTQI+ activist, and film industry leader with over 25 years of experience in the non-profit, film, entertainment, and public sectors. Among her numerous accomplishments, Winnie was the Director of Operations and Events at Inside Out, the presenter of the Toronto and Ottawa 2SLGBTQI+ Film Festivals. She was also the Managing Director of Rainbow Railroad, a charity which supports LGBTQI+ individuals seeking safe haven from around the globe. Her lifelong encounters with mobility disabilities as well as her identities as a Chinese Queer Woman, fuel her passion for advocating for accessibility rights and fostering equity in communities.</p>\n\n<p>Image description is: A black and white photo of a Chinese woman with short black hair, wearing a black and white patterned collared shirt, smiling at the camera with plants in the background.</p>",

        "displayName": "Jeremy Thomas",
        "firstName": "Jeremy",
        "imageUrl": "//web.archive.org/web/20230925131719/https://images.ctfassets.net/22n7d68fswlw/17gm3oa5CfIr6D8PK62v03/f5e5de61f23fa1816b6979b9b861f298/Jeremy-Thomas-Lausanne-March-2019-__-Anoush-Abrar.jpg",
        "imageAlt": "Jeremy-Thomas",
        "title": "",
        "id": "A4PER000004219",
        "sponsorType": "",
        "bio": "<p><strong>JEREMY THOMAS (Producer)</strong> began his film career working in the cutting rooms and soon became an editor. In 1974, Thomas produced his first film, Philippe Mora\u2019s <em>Mad Dog Morgan</em> starring Dennis Hopper, and then founded Recorded Picture Company. Thomas went on to produce many distinctive films, such as Jerzy Skolimowski\u2019s <em>The Shout</em>, Nicolas Roeg\u2019s <em>Bad Timing</em, <em>Eureka</em> and <em>Insignificance</em>, and Nagisa \u00d4shima\u2019s <em>Merry Christmas Mr. Lawrence</em>.</p>\n<p>\n</p>\n<p>In 1986, Thomas collaborated with director Bernardo Bertolucci on <em>The Last Emperor</em>, which won nine Academy Awards\u00ae including Best Picture, and many other international awards. Thomas went on to make <em>Little Buddha</em>,<em>The Sheltering Sky</em>, <em>Stealing Beauty</em> and <em>The Dreamers</em> with Bertolucci in a partnership spanning over 30 years.</p> \n<p>\n</p>\n<p>Thomas has chosen to remain an independent producer, resulting in a diverse body of work, including such titles as David Cronenberg\u2019s <em>Naked Lunch</em>, <em>Crash</em> and <em>A Dangerous Method</em>, Takeshi Kitano\u2019s <em>Brother</em>, Jonathan Glazer\u2019s <em>Sexy Beast</em>, David Mackenzie\u2019s <em>Young Adam</em>, Takashi Miike\u2019s <em>13 Assassins</em>, <em>Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai</em>, <em>Blade of the Immortal</em> and <em>First Love</em>, the Oscar\u00ae-nominated <em>Kon-Tiki</em> by Joachim Roenning and Espen Sandberg, Jim Jarmusch\u2019s <em>Only Lovers Left Alive</em>, Ben Wheatley\u2019s <em>High-Rise, Tale of Tales, Pinocchio</em> and <em>Dogman</em> by Matteo Garrone, and <em>EO</em> by Jerzy Skolimowski.</p>\n<p>\n</p>\n<p>Throughout his career, Thomas has worked with many other leading filmmakers including Stephen Frears, Richard Linklater, Phillip Noyce, Wim Wenders, Terry Gilliam and Bob Rafaelson. In 1992, Thomas was appointed Chairman of the British Film Institute and was made a Life Fellow in 2000. He has been President of the Jury at the Tokyo, San Sebastian, Berlin and Cannes film festivals (Un Certain Regard) and has also served on the main Jury at Cannes.</p>\n<p>\n</p>\n<p>Thomas has produced more than 70 films, 20 of which have premiered at Cannes in Official Selection.</p>",

They will discuss opportunities and challenges specific to the province, including transnational collaborations, content creation for local and international publics, distribution platforms, funding and tax credits, and industry workforce.</p>",

His third feature film, Red Rooms (Les chambres rouges), premiered at the 2023 Karlovy Vary Film Festival.     "description": "<p>This session explores the transformative role archivists play in helping documentary filmmakers monetize their content and mine their archival libraries. From the basement to the C-suite, archivists have become crucial collaborators, working alongside producers and directors to unlock the creative potential of archival material. This discussion brings together esteemed archivists, producers, and directors for an in-depth exploration of the collaborative and creative process involved in making archival cinema a commercially viable and artistically rich endeavor.</p>",

        "displayName": "Elizabeth M. Daley",
        "firstName": "Elizabeth M.",
        "imageUrl": "//web.archive.org/web/20230925131719/https://images.ctfassets.net/22n7d68fswlw/6wRbfnjKKhkZaSPtQXkd4g/bd8affcaf04dd4360b400a42c020ea78/Dean-Elizabeth-Daley-_1_.jpg",
        "imageAlt": "Dean-Elizabeth-Daley-(1)",
        "title": "",
        "id": "A4PER000025419",
        "sponsorType": "",
        "bio": "<p>PhD. Dean, University of Southern California School of Cinematic Arts.</p>\n\n<p>Elizabeth Daley has held the longest tenure of any Dean at the University of Southern California. She is the inaugural holder of the Steven J. Ross/Time Warner Dean\u2019s Chair, founding Executive Director of the USC Annenberg Center for Communication (1994-2005), and serves as the Executive Director of the USC Institute for Multimedia Literacy. Under her leadership, the school has added three new divisions in Animation and Digital Arts, Interactive Media and Games, and Media Arts + Practice; built the Robert Zemeckis Center for Digital Arts; established 33 endowed positions; and formed successful partnerships with a variety of entertainment and technology companies. In 2006, Daley presided over the school\u2019s official renaming as the School of Cinematic Arts by George Lucas and broke ground for a new complex that now includes three instructional buildings, four sound stages and a production center. Before coming to USC, she served as director of the film and television subsidiary of the Mark Taper Forum and was a producer for MGM/Television. She serves on the boards of Avid Technology and the Benton Foundation, and is a former chair of the World Economic Forum\u2019s Global Agenda Council on Media, Entertainment and Information. She is a member of the Directors Guild of America and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. Daley earned a Ph.D. in Communication Arts from the University of Wisconsin and M.A. and B.A. degrees in Theatre from Tulane University.     "description": "<p>A meet and Greet and Roundtable discussion will be led by Prithul Kumar, MD, NFDC.</p>\n\n<p>At the networking event, Ramkumar Vijayan, Consultant (I&B Desk), Film Facilitation Office-Invest India will give a presentation to the international stakeholders about the Film Policies and the potential of co-producing with India. A run-through of the working of the Film Facilitation Office, India\u2019s single window mechanism, will also be given, which promotes ease of filming in the country.</p>\n\n<p>The discussion shall entail topics such as Benefits for Canadian Film Producers for filming in India and how the Co-Production treaty between India and Canada can be revisited and activated for the mutual benefit of the film industries of both the countries. Similarly, Telefilm Canada and Ontario Creates will present the avenues for the Indian filmmakers to produce with Canada.</p>\n\n<p>As a celebration of the cinematic achievements of India and Canada, the countries seek to explore and promote the potential of filmmaking across mediums such as Feature, Short films, Animation Projects, OTT content, and Web Projects.</p>",

    "description": "<p>Now in its 14th year, this competitive event is the last step in the nine-month CaribbeanTales Black Incubator and Studio Access Project (CTBISAP) and the CineFam Limitless Incubator, which champions the creativity of women and non-binary people of colour, which provides Black Canadian filmmakers market-driven training from concept through delivery and monetization to ensure their success in the film and television industry. </p>\r\n \r\n<p>Participants of these programs are supported by CaribbeanTales Media Group in the production and packaging of a short proof of concept for their series or feature film, and 12 will be selected to pitch to an industry jury on September 10, 2023 at the TIFF Bell Lightbox. TIFF industry passholders and the audience will be able to vote for the best presentation along with the industry judges. The 2023 BIG Pitch Edition will stream via CaribbeanTales-TV.</p>\r\n \r\n<p>This year\u2019s BIG Pitch mentors include Founder and CEO of CaribbeanTales Media Group, Frances-Anne Solomon, Director of Engagement and Inclusion at CBC, Nick Davis, Line Producer and Production Manager Moe Rai, Award-winning Director and Producer Sudz Sutherland, and David Hamilton of Hamilton-Mehta Productions.</p>\r\n\r\nThis year's program cohort includes:\r\n<ul>\r\n        <li>Celestina Aleobua & Naira Adedeji with a TV series, <em>Jaded</em></li>\r\n        <li>Andrea Martina Crowther with a feature film <em>Labranza</em></li>\r\n        <li>Mahlena-Rae Johnson with <em>ELLIES</em>, an episodic series</li>\r\n        <li>Atefeh Khademolreza with a TV series, <em>Fish Island</em></li>\r\n        <li>Nauzanin Knight with an animated series, <em>Happy Pappy</em></li>\r\n        <li>KhaR\u00e5 Martin with feature film, <em>Scarborough Love</em></li>\r\n        <li>Giselle Miller with a web series called <em>Novelette is Trying</em></li>\r\n        <li>Vanessa Mitchell with <em>Baked Goods</em>, a TV series</li>\r\n        <li>Chelsea Nyomi with feature film <em>Blooming Dancer</em></li>\r\n        <li>Vicky Plancher with <em>Dorsin and Brown</em>, a feature film</li>\r\n        <li>Lulu Wei with feature documentary, <em>What\u2019s My Name?</em></li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p>Access to Spotlight sessions varies by event partner. With an impressive career spanning over fifteen years, she has garnered international recognition for her filmmaking expertise. Atefeh had the privilege of studying under the late maestro, Abbas Kiarostami, before making the life-changing decision to immigrate to Canada.\nHer compelling films have been showcased at renowned film festivals worldwide, including the prestigious Berlin International Film Festival, Busan International Film Festival, and Vienna International Film Festival. Atefeh&#039;s exceptional talent has earned her the distinguished position of Writer-in-Residence at the Micki Moore Residency hosted by the Toronto International Film Festival (TIFF&#039;21). Moreover, her remarkable achievements secured her a coveted spot in the Netflix-BANFF Diversity of Voices Pitch Program in 2023.\nAtefeh&#039;s commitment to artistic growth has led her to participate in esteemed institutions such as the Berlinale Talent Campus (2006), the Asian Film Academy (2008), the Serbia Interaction Film Camp (2006, 2016), and Reelworld E20 (2019). Her play THE SPIRIT HAS TEETH was selected for the Or Festival and had its world premiere at the Jericho Arts Centre in 2023. One of the reasons Giselle became a filmmaker was to elevate black female voices in the industry and tell the types of stories that she isn&#039;t seeing on screen so that they reflect complex, nuanced images of black people.         "bio": "Vanessa Mitchell is a producer, creator, actress and the co-founder of Madden & Mitchell Media Inc. (MMM) who regards art as activism. Her background in advocacy, youth mentoring and supporting underserved racialized families; propels Vanessa to develop content that authentically represents these diverse stories. Vanessa has worked in the film and television industry as an actress for over 15 years. Seeing the lack of stories being told about Black Canadians and across the diaspora, Vanessa felt the strong desire to create content that explored stories about the black experience and create more opportunities for artists of colour hence the creation of MMM. MMM\u2019s first project was co \u2013produced in association with EMG, a short film called Truth igniting a passion within Vanessa to produce more impactful content for the screen. Vanessa currently is developing two TV series. In co-production with Hungry Eyes Media, a limited drama TV series That Lonesome Road exploring the largely untold stories of Black Canadian Freedom Fighters; Viola Desmond and Carrie Best written by award winning author Lawrence Hill. Her second in partnership with Archipelago Productions is Baked Goods, a serialized drama-comedy that dives into the impacts of marginalization and legalization of cannabis on a racial diverse community in Scarborough through the lens of a Jamaican-Canadian family. Vanessa is an alumnus of the Netflix- Banff Diversity of Voices Initiative, Reelworld Producers and E20 programs, Banff Spark and OYA Scale Up Business Bootcamp.",

        "bio": "Lulu Wei is an award-winning director and filmmaker based in Toronto. Their work delves into themes of space-making, cultural identity, and queerness, reflecting a unique style influenced by their background in commercials and documentary filmmaking. In 2020, their debut feature film, \"There&#039;s No Place Like This Place, Anyplace,\" garnered an audience award at the Hot Docs Canadian International Documentary Festival and received nominations for Best Directing and Best Writing at the 2021 Canadian Screen Awards. Lulu&#039;s sophomore film, \u201cSupporting Our Selves,\u201d premiered as the Centrepiece Gala at the Inside Out Film Festival in 2023, where it won the juried award for Best Canadian Feature. As a cinematographer, they have worked on feature films and documentary series for Vice, Crave, and the CBC. Notably, their cinematography on the award-winning documentary \"Sex With Sue\" (2022) earned them a Canadian Screen Award nomination. Currently in development on their third documentary feature, Lulu continues to explore complex stories, aiming to inspire and engage audiences.         "bio": "Aboubakar Sanogo is an Associate Professor in Film Studies at Carleton University in Ottawa, Canada. His research interests include African cinema; Afro-diasporic cinema; documentary film and media; transnational and world cinema; film archiving and film heritage; colonial cinema; postcolonialism, race, and cinema; and the relationship between film form, history, and theory. \n<br><br>\nHis writings have appeared in <em>Cinema Journal</em>, <em>Framework</em>, <em>Moving Image Review & Art Journal</em>, <em>Rethinking History</em>, <em>Journal of Film Preservation</em>, <em>Film Quarterly</em>, <em>Sight and Sound</em>, <em>Film Comment</em>, and the <em>Journal of African Cinemas</em>. He is currently completing two manuscripts on the history of documentary in Africa and on the cinema of Med Hondo and an anthology on the legendary director.\n<br><br>\nAs the North American Regional Secretary for the Pan African Federation of Filmmakers (FEPACI), he initiated and oversees the FEPACI Archival Project and was instrumental in establishing African Film Heritage Project (AFHP), a major film preservation and restoration initiative in partnership with Martin Scorsese\u2019s The Film Foundation and UNESCO in collaboration with the Cineteca di Bologna.",

        "id": "A4PER000003186",
        "sponsorType": "",
        "bio": "<p>After graduating in audiovisual studies from the University of Beirut, Nadine Labaki directed award-winning adverts and music videos. In 2004, she embarked on a Festival de Cannes Cin\u00e9fondation Residency to write and develop <em>Caramel</em>, her first feature film, shot two years later and showcased at the Directors&#039; Fortnight in 2007. This joyous, rebellious ode to female camaraderie was distributed worldwide and became the most successful Lebanese film export of all time. Labaki continued to explore the female condition and religious tensions in <em>Where Do We Go Now?</em>, which premiered at Un Certain Regard in 2011. In 2018, Nadine Labaki was selected for Competition with her powerfully moving film, <em>Capernaum</em>, and went on to win the Jury Prize at Cannes Film Festival that year, chaired by Cate Blanchett. Nominated for a Golden Globe and Academy Award for Best Foreign Film, <em>Capernaum</em> made Labaki the first woman from the Arabic-speaking world to be nominated in this category.</p>",
